module.name: scrum
module.description:
This is a small MOLGENIS app for the software development process called SCRUM. Also it includes several technical tricks worth mentioning:
A design pattern for versioning (of Tasks)
Use of HTML5 drop-and-drop (of yellow sticky notes on the whiteboard)
Use of HTML5 graphics canvas (to render the burndown chart)
Use of the java.util.Calendar API (to produce example data)
Next to that also steps where made to enable modularity:
this project contains now a gcc.jar which it reuses.
the plugin generators now check if the plugin already exists on classpath. Result is that MOLGENIS will not generate empty plugin boilerplate in handwritten/java and you than have to copy your plugin code into that. Instead you can include the plugin from your other project as *.jar.
the *.properties, *_db.xml and *_ui.xml can now be loaded from class path (instead of local file system). This means MOLGENIS now can load auth.xml from 'shared' inside the gcc.jar instead of needing to copying the file (with all problems to keep that synchronous). Also it makes it easier to move code between projects when refactoring. WE NEED TO MAKE THIS PATH BETTER THAN 'shared'

entity.name: Sprint
entity.description: Sprints are the planning periods of a scrum with clear start and end. Within a Sprint you have a series of stories that a team wants to complete. Typically you

field.name: name
field.description: Unique name for this sprint. E.g. 'sprint 1' or 'sprint 2011.1'

field.name: teamMembers
field.description: Members of this sprint. Every member must be registered this application.

field.name: description
field.description: Most sprints have a mission statement or a slogan. You can put that here :-)

field.name: startOfSprint
field.description: First working day of this sprint. Is used for burndown chart.

field.name: endOfSprint
field.description: Last working day of this sprint, also known as 'demo day'. Is used for the burndown chart.

entity.name: Story
entity.description: Stories describe things that the product owner wants to implement in such a way that we know what to demo end-of-sprint. Each story is addressed in one sprint.

field.name: tracId
field.label: Trac ID
field.description: reference to a ticket ID, typically in TRAC or another ticket tracker.

field.name: howToDemo
field.label: How to demo?
field.description: description of what will be demo-ed when this is story is completed. This is typically a software demo, and in rare occasions a piece of code (for an API) or a report (for a design or evaluation).

field.name: importance
field.description: weight of importance for this story that is used to sort the scrum board.

field.name: linkToDemo
field.label: Link to demo
field.description: Link where one can view the demo that was produced as result of story.

field.name: sprint
field.description: Sprint that this story is part of.

entity.name: TaskInterface
entity.description: In order to allow recording of Task history we have two tables: Task and TaskHistory. Both tables are identical EXCEPT that the TaskHistory does have each unique contraint with an added version. Making both inherit from the same interface allows easy programming against both the main class (Task) and its history (TaskHistory).

field.name: tracId
field.label: Trac ID
field.description: reference to a ticket ID, typically in TRAC or another ticket tracker.

field.name: description
field.description: A short sentence that explains what involved. Maximum 255 characters.

field.name: changedOn
field.description: Date on which this task was last change. (list TaskHistory for the full list of changes)

field.name: story
field.description: Reference to the story this task is part of.

field.name: storyPoints
field.description: An estimate for the amount of work. In most teams a story point equals 1 day of work

field.name: owner
field.description: The team member currently responsible for the task. Note that typically multiple people work on a task but the product owner can call this person to see what is happening.

field.name: status
field.description: Status of the task. Usual workflow is: schedules (new), checked (in progress), and done (ready). Sometimes it turns out a taks was not necessary and then it can be removed.

entity.name: Task
entity.description: Main Task table that has all constraints like always. The TaskDecorator takes care of versioning. TODO: generalize this.

unique.description: A tasks must have a unique description within one story (to prevent duplicate tasks).

entity.name: TaskHistory
entity.description: Shadow table for Task. All unique constraints are extended with 'version'. This data is automatically maintained via the TaskDecorator of the Task class.
